content: PMS usually occurs in the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, which is the phase after ovulation and before menstruation. The prevalence of PMS varies among women, with some experiencing mild symptoms while others have more severe and debilitating symptoms.

Lifestyle changes, such as regular exercise, a healthy diet, and stress management techniques, may help alleviate PMS symptoms. Certain dietary factors, such as reducing salt, sugar, caffeine, and alcohol intake, may help improve PMS symptoms.

Vitamin and mineral supplements, particularly calcium and vitamin B6, may help alleviate PMS symptoms for some women. Some women may experience gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, constipation, or diarrhea during PMS.
Keeping a symptom diary can help track the timing and severity of PMS symptoms, which can assist in diagnosis and treatment.
